text: this is kit Eaton for the New York Times
there are times when a smartphone really
can be a musician's best friend for
example apps like tune wave come in
really handy when you need to tune your
stringed instrument tuned wave is a
one-dollar ios app that may be able to
replace the standalone unit you carry
around with your guitar essentially the
app uses your phone's microphone to
listen to the strings of your guitar as
you pluck them and the extras like being
able to transpose the notes and if
you're a violinist or cellist you can
also use this app tune wave a simple
straightforward and I like it a lot
using a metronome can be very handy when
you're learning to play a new piece of
music and free Android app metronome
beats is a great example of an app that
does this job for you basically a direct
replacement for an electronic or analog
metronome metronome beats lets you
change the pace at which it ticks of
course and it has a few nice extras like
being able to use custom sounds to mark
the time audibly the apps are
straightforward design easy-to-use
controls and maybe my only criticism is
that display can sometimes get a little
bit busy which may be distracting when
you're trying to play a piece of music
lastly musicians of all types should
check out deep-dish gig booked an app
which costs ten dollars on iOS gig book
is essentially a digital storage device
for sheet music thus saving you the
bother of carrying around real paper
copies but just like real musical scores
you can annotate the music with all
sorts of reminders that you may need
like timings or fingerings submitting
PDF copies of sheet music to the app is
pretty easy and it's even compatible
with page-turning peripherals which
makes the task of turning the digital
page to the next section of music even
easier at ten dollars the app may sound
expensive but it's got a lot going for
it and that's it from me have fun making
music
Oh
